elements.content: Four pairs of enantiomeric dysprosium­(III) phosphonates, namely, R- or S-[Dy3(pempH2)2­(pempH)7]2­(NO3)4­·12H2O ( R -1 or S -1), R- or S-[Dy3(pempH)7­(pempH2)2]­Cl2­·2H2O ( R -2 or S -2), R- or S-[Dy3(pempH)7­(pempH2)2]­Br2­·2H2O ( R -3 or S -3), and R- or S-[Dy11(pempH2)6­(pempH)27]­(CF3SO3)6­·22H2O ( R -4 or S -4) are reported, where R- or S-pempH2 represent R- or S-(1-phenylethyl)­amino] methylphosphonic acid. All show homochiral chain structures, charge-balanced by counteranions. A comparison of the crystal morphologies of the R-isomers reveals that the overall shapes are quite similar for the four compounds, but the aspect ratio changes remarkably following the sequence: R -1 < R -2 < R -3 < R -4. The sequence is in agreement with the decreasing interchain interactions related to different counteranions, which is rationalized by molecular simulations. The counteranions also influence the intrachain structures and the local coordination environments of the DyIII ions. As a result, compounds R -2 and R -3 exhibit distinct dual relaxation processes at zero dc field with the effective energy barriers for the slow- and fast-relaxation being 79.1 and 37.6 K for R -2, and 80.0 and 39.1 K for R -3, respectively. For compounds R -1 and R -4, however, slow magnetic relaxation is also observed at zero dc field but without the appearance of maxima down to 1.8 K.

elements.content: Four pairs of enantiomeric DyIII phosphonates in which positively charged chains are separated by counteranions are reported. Both the morphologies of the resulting crystals and the magnetic behavior are significantly affected by the anions, associated with the interchain interactions.

elements.content: The growth of crystalline materials with well-defined morphologies and compositions is not only synthetically interesting, but also important for the development of functional materials. Tremendous efforts have been devoted to the syntheses of inorganic and organic crystals or nanocrystals with controlled sizes and shapes showing size- and facet-dependent electric, optical, magnetic, and catalytic properties. As an important class of crystalline materials, coordination polymers (CPs) and especially metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are recognized to have promising potential in applications for gas sorption/separation, catalysis, energy devices, and medicine. In order to integrate novel functions into these materials, increasing attention has been paid to control of the size and morphology of MOFs or CPs on the nano-/microscale via different approaches such as solvent, pH, metal source, reactant concentration, temperature, additives, and reverse emulsions. In contrast, crystal growth and morphology control on the bulk-scale are much less explored for MOFs or CPs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The growth of crystalline materials with well-defined morphologies and compositions is not only synthetically interesting, but also important for the development of functional materials. Tremendous efforts have been devoted to the syntheses of inorganic and organic crystals or nanocrystals with controlled sizes and shapes showing size- and facet-dependent electric, optical, magnetic, and catalytic properties. As an important class of crystalline materials, coordination polymers (CPs) and especially metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are recognized to have promising potential in applications for gas sorption/separation, catalysis, energy devices, and medicine. In order to integrate novel functions into these materials, increasing attention has been paid to control of the size and morphology of MOFs or CPs on the nano-/microscale via different approaches such as solvent, pH, metal source, reactant concentration, temperature, additives, and reverse emulsions. In contrast, crystal growth and morphology control on the bulk-scale are much less explored for MOFs or CPs.

elements.content: In principle, crystal growth is mainly determined by their intrinsic structures. For example, the crystal morphology of a chain compound can be a competitive result of the growth rates along the chain and between the chains (). When the interchain interaction is comparable to the intrachain interaction, block-like crystals could be obtained. When the interchain interaction is weak enough, rod-like or needle-like crystals would be expected. Thus, we envisage that for compounds containing positively or negatively charged chains, it is possible to control the morphology or the aspect ratio of the resulting crystals using different counterions. In other words, the morphology of the chain compound can serve as a “probe” to detect qualitatively the strength of the interactions between the chain and different counterions. Furthermore, the counterion may also affect the intrachain structure slightly, and hence the function of the chain compounds can be modulated by using different counterions.

elements.content: On the basis of the enantiopure R- or S-(1-phenylethyl)­amino] methylphosphonic acids (pempH2), we have isolated a series of compounds showing homochiral chain, layer, and framework structures. More recently we reported three types of Tb/pemp compounds with either crystalline or helical morphologies. It was found that the morphologies and compositions of the Tb/pemp compounds are dependent on pH of the reaction mixture, e.g., block-like crystals of R-, S-(H3O)­[Tb3(pempH2)2­(pempH)7]­[Tb3(pempH2)­(pempH)8]­(NO3)4­·12H2O at lower pH, rod-like crystals of R-,S-[Tb­(pempH)3]­·2H2O at higher pH, and helices of R-,S-[Tb­(pempH)3]­·2H2O when the pH is in between. In the block-like crystals, positively charged Tb/pemp chains are found, which are balanced by the nitrate anions.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the enantiopure R- or S-(1-phenylethyl)amino] methylphosphonic acids (pempH2), we have isolated a series of compounds showing homochiral chain, layer, and framework structures. More recently we reported three types of Tb/pemp compounds with either crystalline or helical morphologies. It was found that the morphologies and compositions of the Tb/pemp compounds are dependent on pH of the reaction mixture, e.g., block-like crystals of R-, S-(H3O)[Tb3(pempH2)2(pempH)7][Tb3(pempH2)(pempH)8](NO3)4⋅12H2O at lower pH, rod-like crystals of R-,S-[Tb(pempH)3]⋅2H2O at higher pH, and helices of R-,S-[Tb(pempH)3]⋅2H2O when the pH is in between. In the block-like crystals, positively charged Tb/pemp chains are found, which are balanced by the nitrate anions.

elements.content: In order to investigate the effect of counteranions on the crystal morphology and properties of the lanthanide/pemp compounds, herein we select different dysprosium salts, Dy­(NO3)3, DyCl3, DyBr3, and Dy­(CF3SO3)3, to react with pempH2 under similar hydrothermal conditions. The dysprosium ion is chosen because of the previous success by using this ion in constructing single ion magnets (SIM) and single molecule magnets (SMM) owing to its large magnetic anisotropy arising from strong spin–orbit coupling and its Kramers ground state. Consequently, four pairs of homochiral compounds are obtained with formulas R-,S-[Dy3(pempH2)2­(pempH)7]2­(NO3)4­·12H2O ( R -1, S -1), R-,S-[Dy3(pempH2)2­(pempH)7]­Cl2­·2H2O ( R -2, S -2), R-,S-[Dy3(pempH2)2­(pempH)7]­Br2­·1.5H2O ( R -3, S -3), and R-,S-[Dy11(pempH2)6­(pempH)27]­(CF3SO3)6­·22H2O ( R -4, S -4). All show positively charged chain structures with the counteranions reside between the chains. A comparison of the crystal morphologies of the R-isomers reveals that the overall shapes are quite similar for the four compounds, but the aspect ratio changes remarkably following the sequence: R -1 < R -2 < R -3 < R -4. To understand in-depth the growth mechanism of these crystals with regular aspect ratio, molecular simulations are performed to explore how the nature and strength of chemical interactions between counteranions and cationic chains affect the crystal morphologies. Further, the counteranions also affect the intrachain structure and the local coordination environments of the DyIII ions, leading to different magnetic behaviors. The SMM behavior is evident for compounds 2 and 3 containing Cl– and Br– anions under zero dc field, whereas compounds 1 and 4 containing NO3 – and CF3SO3 – anions show slow magnetization relaxation without the appearance of maxima down to 1.8 K. It is worth mentioning that homochiral dysprosium chain compounds showing SMM behavior are extremely rare.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. R- and S-(1-Phenylethylamino)­methyl phosphonic acid (pempH2) were prepared according to a literature method. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 using KBr pellets. Thermal analyses were performed using a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC thermoanalyzer in a temperature range 25–500 °C in N2 flow (20 mL/min) with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) in a range of 5.00–50.00° at room temperature. The circular dichroism spectra were recorded on a JASCO–1500 spectropolarimeter using KCl pellets at room temperature. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed with a Quantum Design PPMS system. The diamagnetic contribution of the sample was estimated from Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. R- and S-(1-Phenylethylamino)methyl phosphonic acid (pempH2) were prepared according to a literature method. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 using KBr pellets. Thermal analyses were performed using a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC thermoanalyzer in a temperature range 25-500 °C in N2 flow (20 mL/min) with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) in a range of 5.00-50.00° at room temperature. The circular dichroism spectra were recorded on a JASCO-1500 spectropolarimeter using KCl pellets at room temperature. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed with a Quantum Design PPMS system. The diamagnetic contribution of the sample was estimated from Pascal's constants.

elements.content: The two compounds were synthesized similarly. A typical procedure for the preparation of R -1 is described as below. A mixture of Dy­(NO3)3­·6H2O (0.0456 g, 0.1 mmol), R-pempH2 (0.1080 g, 0.5 mmol) in 10 mL of water, adjusted to pH 2.8 with 0.5 M NaOH solution, was kept in a 10 mL Teflon-lined stainless container and heated at 120 °C for 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, colorless block-like crystals of R -1 were collected by suction filtration and washed with a minimum amount of water. Yield: 35.0 mg (38.4% based on Dy). Elemental analysis (%) calcd. for C162H262N22O78P18Dy6: C, 36.72; H, 4.98; N, 5.81. Found: C, 36.37; H, 5.14; N, 5.32. elements.content: Single crystals of compounds R -1, R -2, S -2, R -3, S -3, and R -4 were selected for indexing and intensity data collection on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The data were integrated using the Siemens SAINT program, with the intensities corrected for Lorentz factor, polarization, air absorption, and absorption due to variation in the path length through the detector face plate. Absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using SHELXTL. All the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps and were refined anisotropically. All H atoms were refined isotropically with the isotropic vibration parameters related to the non-hydrogen atoms to which they are bonded. The crystallographic data are listed in , and the selected bond lengths and angles are given in Tables S1–S10.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystals of compounds  R  -1,  R  -2,  S  -2,  R  -3,  S  -3, and  R  -4 were selected for indexing and intensity data collection on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The data were integrated using the Siemens SAINT program, with the intensities corrected for Lorentz factor, polarization, air absorption, and absorption due to variation in the path length through the detector face plate. Absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using SHELXTL. All the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps and were refined anisotropically. All H atoms were refined isotropically with the isotropic vibration parameters related to the non-hydrogen atoms to which they are bonded. The crystallographic data are listed in , and the selected bond lengths and angles are given in Tables S1-S10.

The all-atom MD simulations were performed by using Gromacs 5.0.4 package with the Amber force field. The TIP3P water model was chosen. The force-field parameter for pempH– was built by using Antechamber tool. The parameter for halide ions (i.e., Cl–, Br–) was adopt by Joung et al., and that for DyIII and NO3 – was adopt by Li et al. and Liu et al. respectively. In MD simulations, the temperature was coupled at 300 K using the Nosé–Hoover method. The cutoff of Lennard-Jones (LJ) interaction was 1.2 nm. The Particle Mesh Ewald (PME) method was used to calculate the electrostatic interactions. The periodic boundary conditions were applied in all three dimensions. The time step was chosen as 2 fs, and each simulation was conducted for at least 50 ns.
elements.clean_text:
All-Atom Molecular Dynamics (MD) Simulation

The all-atom MD simulations were performed by using Gromacs 5.0.4 package with the Amber force field. The TIP3P water model was chosen. The force-field parameter for pempH- was built by using Antechamber tool. The parameter for halide ions (i.e., Cl-, Br-) was adopt by Joung et al., and that for DyIII and NO3 - was adopt by Li et al. and Liu et al. respectively. In MD simulations, the temperature was coupled at 300 K using the Nosé-Hoover method. The cutoff of Lennard-Jones (LJ) interaction was 1.2 nm. The Particle Mesh Ewald (PME) method was used to calculate the electrostatic interactions. The periodic boundary conditions were applied in all three dimensions. The time step was chosen as 2 fs, and each simulation was conducted for at least 50 ns.

elements.content: In order to better understand the role of anion in the self-assembly at a larger space scale, BD simulations were also used. Here, the DyIII ion was treated as one (green) bead (i.e., Dy bead), and the R-pempH– molecule was simplified as two beads, where the ochre bead (i.e., P1 bead) can interact with each other to promote the growth along the side direction, and the pink bead (i.e., P2 bead) can interact with the Dy bead to promote the growth along the chain direction. The harmonic spring interaction U s = k s(l i,i+1 – l 0)2 was applied between the connected beads in the molecule, where k s = 3000 k B T 0/r0 2, l 0 = 0.4r 0. In order to depict the attractive interaction of the Dy bead - P2 bead, the P1 bead - P1 bead, the Lennard-Jones potential was used (r cut = 0.6 r0, σ = 0.4r 0). Similar to previous study, we set ϵDy‑p2 = 15.0 k B T and ϵp1‑p1 = 3.0 k B T (in the presence of NO3 –). Besides, ϵp1‑p1 is set as 2.5 k B T (in the presence of Cl–), 2.3 k B T (in the presence of Br–), 1.5 k B T (in the presence of CF3SO3 –) respectively, which is according to their relative values of interaction energy in all-atom simulations. The monomer for the assembly in the simulations was chosen as six Dy beads with 18 P1 beads and 18 P2 beads. In addition, the initial coordinate of Dy beads and P1 beads (in the monomer) was obtained by using the coordinate of DyIII ion and P atom (of R-pempH– molecule) in experimental crystal data, respectively. Moreover, for the sake of simplicity, Dy beads and P1 beads in each monomer were treated as rigid ones in BD simulation.
elements.clean_text:
Brownian Dynamics (BD) Simulation

In order to better understand the role of anion in the self-assembly at a larger space scale, BD simulations were also used. Here, the DyIII ion was treated as one (green) bead (i.e., Dy bead), and the R-pempH- molecule was simplified as two beads, where the ochre bead (i.e., P1 bead) can interact with each other to promote the growth along the side direction, and the pink bead (i.e., P2 bead) can interact with the Dy bead to promote the growth along the chain direction. The harmonic spring interaction U s = k s(l  i,i+1  - l 0)2 was applied between the connected beads in the molecule, where k s = 3000 k B T 0/r0 2, l 0 = 0.4r 0. In order to depict the attractive interaction of the Dy bead - P2 bead, the P1 bead - P1 bead, the Lennard-Jones potential was used (r cut = 0.6 r0, σ = 0.4r 0). Similar to previous study, we set ϵDy-p2 = 15.0 k B T and ϵp1-p1 = 3.0 k B T (in the presence of NO3 -). Besides, ϵp1-p1 is set as 2.5 k B T (in the presence of Cl-), 2.3 k B T (in the presence of Br-), 1.5 k B T (in the presence of CF3SO3 -) respectively, which is according to their relative values of interaction energy in all-atom simulations. The monomer for the assembly in the simulations was chosen as six Dy beads with 18 P1 beads and 18 P2 beads. In addition, the initial coordinate of Dy beads and P1 beads (in the monomer) was obtained by using the coordinate of DyIII ion and P atom (of R-pempH- molecule) in experimental crystal data, respectively. Moreover, for the sake of simplicity, Dy beads and P1 beads in each monomer were treated as rigid ones in BD simulation.

elements.content: All BD simulations were performed in the NVT ensemble by using the LAMMPS package (15 May 2015). In BD simulations, as did in the experiments, the temperature was first coupled at 1.3T 0 (about 390 K or 120 °C) in the initial 10000τ and then decreased to 1.0T 0 (about 300 K, i.e., room temperature) using the Langevin thermostat. The time step was 0.006τ, and the data were collected every 60τ, with the total simulation time larger than 30000τ.

The time step was 0.006τ, and the data were collected every 60τ, with the total simulation time larger than 30000τ.

elements.content: Compounds 1–4 were prepared under similar experimental conditions except for dysprosium salts DyX3 (X = NO3 –, Cl–, Br–, CF3SO3 –). The R- and S-isomers show identical powder XRD patterns, IR spectra, and CD spectra with opposite Cotton effect signals (Figures S1–S12), confirming the enantiomeric nature of the isomers. The CD signals of all four pairs of R- and S-isomers appear at 260 nm, which agree well with those of the pure ligands (), indicating that the chirality of the compounds originates from the chiral ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Characterization

Compounds 1-4 were prepared under similar experimental conditions except for dysprosium salts DyX3 (X = NO3 -, Cl-, Br-, CF3SO3 -). The R- and S-isomers show identical powder XRD patterns, IR spectra, and CD spectra with opposite Cotton effect signals (Figures S1-S12), confirming the enantiomeric nature of the isomers. The CD signals of all four pairs of R- and S-isomers appear at 260 nm, which agree well with those of the pure ligands (), indicating that the chirality of the compounds originates from the chiral ligands.

elements.content: Thermal analyses show a two-step decomposition for 1 (Figure S13). The weight losses below 100 °C are 4.1% for R -1 and 3.9% for S -1, attributed to the release of 12 water molecules (calcd: 4.1%). The dehydrated samples are stable up to 220 °C, above which a second-step weight-loss is observed with collapse of the structures. For compounds 2 and 3, the weight losses below 200 °C are 1.5% for R -2, 1.2% for S -2, and 0.3% for R -3 and S -3, attributed to the removal of two and a half water molecules (calcd: 1.4% for 2, 0.3% for 3), respectively. After increasing of the temperature to 260 °C, a second-step weight-loss is observed with collapse of the structures (Figures S14 and S15). For compound 4, thermal analysis reveals a weight loss of 3.9% for R -4 and 3.6% for S -4 on heating to 100 °C, corresponding to the release of 22 lattice water molecules (calcd: 3.9%). A plateau appears between 100 and 260 °C, suggesting that the dehydrated compound is stable up to 260 °C. Above 260 °C, the compound is decomposed, and the structure is collapsed (Figure S16).

elements.content: and S17 show the SEM images of the crystals of the R-isomers of compounds 1–4. For each compound, 10 single crystals were selected randomly from the bulk sample to measure their lengths and widths. The results are listed in Table S1. The morphology of the crystals of R -1 is block-like with 12 distinct facets, whereas the crystals of R -2, R -3, and R -4 are rod-like with similar morphology except that one direction is elongated significantly. The average aspect (length/width) ratios are 1.29 for R -1, 2.28 for R -2, 2.82 for R -3, and 4.61 for R -4, respectively. The larger the aspect ratio, the faster growing rate is along the chain direction. Apparently, the crystal growth of these compounds is highly dependent on the specific anions used in the system. The lateral growth rate decreases in the order: R -1 (NO3 –) > R -2 (Cl–) > R -3 (Br–) > R -4 (CF3SO3 –). The result suggests that the interactions between the chain and the counteranions decrease in the order: NO3 – > Cl– > Br– > CF3SO3 –.

elements.content: In order to get insight into how the anions are involved in the structures and play a role in crystal growth, single-crystal structure determination was conducted for all compounds except S -1 and S -4 (). Single crystals of S -1 and S -4 with good quality cannot be obtained. Since the R- and S-isomers are enantiomeric, only the structures of the R-isomers are described in detail.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Descriptions

In order to get insight into how the anions are involved in the structures and play a role in crystal growth, single-crystal structure determination was conducted for all compounds except  S  -1 and  S  -4 (). Single crystals of  S  -1 and  S  -4 with good quality cannot be obtained. Since the R- and S-isomers are enantiomeric, only the structures of the R-isomers are described in detail.

elements.content: Compound R -1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, chiral space group P21 (No. 4). The asymmetric unit is composed of six crystallographically distinguished DyIII ions, 14 R-pempH–, 4 R-pempH2, 4 NO3 –, and 12 lattice water molecules (Figure S18). The amino nitrogen atoms in both R-pempH– and R-pempH2 are protonated. The neutral R-pempH2 molecule is a zwitterion with a singly protonated phosphonate group, whereas the phosphonate group in the R-pempH– anion is fully deprotonated. Two structurally different chains are identified in R -1, although they possess the same composition of [Dy3(R-pempH2)2­(R-pempH)7]2+ (a,b). Each contains three distinct Dy atoms (Dy1, Dy2, and Dy3 for chain-I, Dy4, Dy5, and Dy6 for chain-II). The Dy–O bond lengths fall in the range 2.259(12)–2.757(15) Å, and the O–Dy–O bond angles are 56.3(5)–168.5(4)° (Table S2). The R-pempH– ligands each act as a tridentate or bidentate ligand, chelating and bridging two adjacent DyIII ions (modes A and B, ). The two R-pempH2 molecules are singly protonated at O18 and O26 (in chain-I) or at O29 and O54 (in chain-II), acting as a bidentate ligand to connect neighboring DyIII ions (mode C, ).

elements.clean_text: 2  Molecular Structure of the Phosphonate Ligand pempH2, and Its Coordination Modes with Dysprosium Ions in Structures 1-4

elements.content: The main difference between chain-I and chain–II is 2-fold: (1) The coordination geometries of the Dy atoms are different. In chain-I all three Dy atoms are 8-coordinated, while in chain-II two Dy atoms (Dy4, Dy5) are 8-coordinated and one (Dy6) is 7-coordinated. (2) The connecting modes of the Dy atoms within the chains are different. In chain-I, neighboring Dy atoms are triply bridged by two μ-O­(P) and one O–P–O units into infinite chains running along the b-axis. The Dy···Dy distances are 3.9965(6) Å for Dy1···Dy2, 4.0024(16) Å for Dy2···Dy3, and 4.1479(7) Å for Dy1···Dy3. In chain-II, however, the Dy atoms are triply bridged by two μ-O­(P) and one O–P–O units to form a trimer. Between the trimers, the 7- and 8-coordinated Dy atoms (Dy6 and Dy4) are connected by one μ-O­(P) and two O–P–O units into a chain. As a result, the Dy4···Dy6 distance [4.3577(7) Å] is much longer than those of Dy4···Dy5 [3.8896(6) Å] and Dy5···Dy6 [3.9019(6) Å]. Triple helical strands made up of one -Dy–O-P–O-Dy- and two -Dy–O-Dy- are found in both kinds of chains. The pitch and diameter are 24.11 and 18.87 Å for chain-I, and 24.11 and 17.80 Å for chain-II, respectively (Figure S19).

In chain-II, however, the Dy atoms are triply bridged by two μ-O(P) and one O-P-O units to form a trimer. Between the trimers, the 7- and 8-coordinated Dy atoms (Dy6 and Dy4) are connected by one μ-O(P) and two O-P-O units into a chain. Triple helical strands made up of one -Dy-O-P-O-Dy- and two -Dy-O-Dy- are found in both kinds of chains. The pitch and diameter are 24.11 and 18.87 Å for chain-I, and 24.11 and 17.80 Å for chain-II, respectively (Figure S19).

elements.content: The individual chain-I and chain-II of R -1 are well isolated in the lattice with extensive hydrogen-bonding interactions between the chains (a and Table S3). The shortest interchain Dy···Dy separation is 14.941 Å. Four crystallographically distinguished NO3 – anions (N19, N20, N21, and N22) exist as charge-balancing counterions between the chains. They are involved in the hydrogen bonds with the protonated phosphonate oxygen atoms (O18···O63:2.52 Å, O26···O64:3.10 Å, O26···O65:2.67 Å, O29···O55:2.47 Å). Extensive hydrogen bond network is observed among the protonated and pending phosphonate oxygen, amino nitrogen, −CH2– and phenyl groups as well as lattice water molecules. Thus, a three-dimensional supramolecular structure is stabilized (Figure S20).

elements.content: Compound R -2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group P212121 (No. 19). Its asymmetric unit consists of three distinct DyIII, two R-pempH2, seven R-pempH–, two Cl–, and two lattice water molecules (Figure S21). This compound also shows a positively charged chain structure, balanced by Cl– anion. Both the composition and the structure of the chain in R -2 are identical to that of chain-II in R -1. In this case, the Dy1 atom is 7-coordinated, and the Dy2 and Dy3 are 8-coordinated (c). The Dy–O bond lengths and O–Dy–O angles are 2.231(7)–2.568(6) Å, and 58.2(2)–170.3(3)°, respectively (Table S4). Within the chain, a trimer unit in which the Dy atoms are triply bridged by two μ-O­(P) and one O–P–O units is again observed [Dy1···Dy2:3.901(1) Å, Dy2···Dy3:3.969(1) Å]. The trimers are further cross-linked by one μ-O­(P) and two O–P–O units into an infinite chain [Dy1···Dy3:4.432(1) Å]. The chain is again helical showing a left handedness composed of triple strands. The pitch and diameter are 24.28 and 18.76 Å, respectively (Figure S22). The shortest Dy···Dy distance between the chains is 14.824 Å.

Its asymmetric unit consists of three distinct DyIII, two R-pempH2, seven R-pempH-, two Cl-, and two lattice water molecules (Figure S21). This compound also shows a positively charged chain structure, balanced by Cl- anion. Both the composition and the structure of the chain in  R  -2 are identical to that of chain-II in  R  -1. In this case, the Dy1 atom is 7-coordinated, and the Dy2 and Dy3 are 8-coordinated (c). The Dy-O bond lengths and O-Dy-O angles are 2.231(7)-2.568(6) Å, and 58.2(2)-170.3(3)°, respectively (Table S4). Within the chain, a trimer unit in which the Dy atoms are triply bridged by two μ-O(P) and one O-P-O units is again observed [Dy1⋅⋅⋅Dy2:3.901(1) Å, Dy2⋅⋅⋅Dy3:3.969(1) Å]. The trimers are further cross-linked by one μ-O(P) and two O-P-O units into an infinite chain [Dy1⋅⋅⋅Dy3:4.432(1) Å]. The chain is again helical showing a left handedness composed of triple strands. The pitch and diameter are 24.28 and 18.76 Å, respectively (Figure S22). The shortest Dy⋅⋅⋅Dy distance between the chains is 14.824 Å.

elements.content: The Cl– counteranions are located between the chains and are involved in the hydrogen bonding to the protonated phosphonate O atoms [O24···Cl1:2.996 Å, O6···Cl2:3.048 Å], and amino nitrogen atoms [N8···Cl1:3.126 Å]. The lattice water molecules also form hydrogen bonds with the phosphonate and amino nitrogen atoms (b, Table S5). Noting that the C–H···Cl hydrogen bonds are very weak [C78···Cl1:3.737 Å, C68···Cl1:3.737 Å], the interchain interactions are dominated by the van der Waals interactions. Obviously, compared to R -1, the interactions between the adjacent chains in R -2 become much weaker.

Noting that the C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl hydrogen bonds are very weak [C78⋅⋅⋅Cl1:3.737 Å, C68⋅⋅⋅Cl1:3.737 Å], the interchain interactions are dominated by the van der Waals interactions. Obviously, compared to  R  -1, the interactions between the adjacent chains in  R  -2 become much weaker.

elements.content: Compound R -3 is isostructural to compound R -2 except that the counter chloride anion in R -2 is replaced by the bromine anion (Figure S24). This compound shows a helical chain structure, which is identical to that in R -2, although slight differences in the bond lengths and angles are observed (d, Table S7). The pitch and diameter of the triple-stranded chain are 24.27 and 18.95 Å (Figure S25), close to those in compound R -2. The Dy···Dy distances within the chain are 3.895(1), 3.968(1) and 4.447(1) Å, respectively. The shortest Dy···Dy distance between the chains is 14.419 Å. The bromide anions are involved in the hydrogen bonds with the protonated phosphonate oxygen (O6···Br2:3.185 Å, O24···Br1:3.154 Å), amino group (N2···Br2, 3.293 Å, N8···Br1:3.261 Å), and phenyl group (C68···Br1:3.760 Å) (c, Table S8). Due to the decrease of electronegativity as well as the increase of ionic radii, the strength of interactions between the chain and counteranion in R -3 could become weaker compared to that in R -2.

elements.content: Compound R -4 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, chiral space group P21 (No. 4), similar to compound R -1. However, the unit cell volume is significantly expanded, almost double that of R -1. In this case, the asymmetric unit includes 11 crystallographically independent DyIII ion, 6 zwitterion R-pempH2, 27 singly protonated R-pempH– anion, 6 CF3SO3 – counteranion, and 22 lattice water molecules (Figure S27). Unlike compounds 1–3, all of the Dy atoms are 8-coordinated and adopt distorted dodecahedron geometries, surrounded by eight phosphonate oxygen atoms from six phosphonate ligands (e). The Dy–O bond lengths are 2.204(8)–2.602(8) Å, and the O–Dy–O bond angles are 58.8(3)–164.4(3)° (Table S10). The R-pempH– and R-pempH2 serve as bidentate or tridentate ligands chelating and bridging the Dy atoms (modes A–D, ). Consequently, the adjacent DyIII ions are periodically bridged by pairs of μ-O­(P) and one O–P–O group mediators, generating an infinite chain containing triple strands that run along the a-axis (e). The Dy···Dy distances within the chain are 3.897–4.026 Å. Although the diameter of the helical chain (17.61 Å) is close to those in structures 1–3, the pitch (43.43 Å) is significantly longer (Figure S28). Six crystallographically distinguished CF3SO3 – anions exist as charge-balancing counterions filling the space between the chains, one of which is disordered over two sites. The anions are involved in the hydrogen bonds with the protonated phosphonate oxygen (O39···O113: 3.013 Å, O45···O104: 2.705 Å) and phenyl groups (C···O: 3.2–3.45 Å, C···F: 3.06–3.29 Å) (Table S11). Compared with those in 1–3, there are much fewer O···O and no N···O hydrogen bonds between the chain and the anion, possibly due to the relatively large size of CF3SO3 –. The chains are packed in the lattice and are stabilized by the weak hydrogen bonds and the van der Waals interactions (Figure S29). The shortest interchain Dy···Dy distance is 15.153 Å, much longer than those in compounds 1–3.

elements.content: To give a possible explanation for the experimental phenomenon and provide more physical insights into the effect of anion type on the crystal morphology (especially the aspect ratio of crystals), we then applied all-atom molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to investigate the interaction energy of R-pempH– systems containing different anions (see a–d). Similar to the previous study of TbIII, the interaction energy between DyIII and R-pempH– molecule is also the largest, indicating that the growth rate along the chain direction should be faster than that along the side direction. Besides, in the presence of anion, the side interaction between the R-pempH–/R-pempH2 molecules could be enhanced due to the hydrogen bonds between the anion and R-pempH–/R-pempH2 molecules. As shown in e, the mean interaction energy between the R-pempH–/R-pempH2 molecules is about 40 kJ/mol (in the presence of Br–), much larger than that in the absence of any anion (∼17 kJ/mol). Besides, the interaction energy will become larger with the increase of the electronegativity of the anion (i.e., 44 kJ/mol in the presence of Cl– and 52 kJ/mol in the presence of NO3 –). Nevertheless, due to its large size, CF3SO3 – may just reside in the top interchain space of two molecules and thereby cannot efficiently form the hydrogen bond. As a result, the interaction energy in the presence of CF3SO3 – is the lowest (∼26 kJ/mol). In short, since the side interaction increases from CF3SO3 –, Br–, Cl– to NO3 –, the growth rate between the chain direction and side direction would become less obvious, leading to the different aspect ratios of the crystals in these cases.
elements.clean_text:
Molecular Modeling

To give a possible explanation for the experimental phenomenon and provide more physical insights into the effect of anion type on the crystal morphology (especially the aspect ratio of crystals), we then applied all-atom molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to investigate the interaction energy of R-pempH- systems containing different anions (see a-d). Similar to the previous study of TbIII, the interaction energy between DyIII and R-pempH- molecule is also the largest, indicating that the growth rate along the chain direction should be faster than that along the side direction. Besides, in the presence of anion, the side interaction between the R-pempH-/R-pempH2 molecules could be enhanced due to the hydrogen bonds between the anion and R-pempH-/R-pempH2 molecules. As shown in e, the mean interaction energy between the R-pempH-/R-pempH2 molecules is about 40 kJ/mol (in the presence of Br-), much larger than that in the absence of any anion (~17 kJ/mol). Besides, the interaction energy will become larger with the increase of the electronegativity of the anion (i.e., 44 kJ/mol in the presence of Cl- and 52 kJ/mol in the presence of NO3 -). Nevertheless, due to its large size, CF3SO3 - may just reside in the top interchain space of two molecules and thereby cannot efficiently form the hydrogen bond. As a result, the interaction energy in the presence of CF3SO3 - is the lowest (~26 kJ/mol). In short, since the side interaction increases from CF3SO3 -, Br-, Cl- to NO3 -, the growth rate between the chain direction and side direction would become less obvious, leading to the different aspect ratios of the crystals in these cases.

The water molecules and counterions are not shown for clarity. (e) Interaction energy among different molecules in the above systems.

The water molecules and counterions are not shown for clarity. (e) Interaction energy among different molecules in the above systems.

elements.content: The above all-atom simulation may provide some hints for the anion effect on the assembly at the microscopic level. However, due to the limited time and length scale of all-atom simulation, it is still very difficult to compare the simulation and experimental results directly. To better clarify the experimental observations, we further used Brownian dynamics (BD) simulation to investigate the system from the mesoscopic view (a–b). As shown in c, due to the strong side interaction, the assembled rod has a comparable length and width in R -1 (the ratio is in the range of 2.1–3.1, see Table S12). With the decrease of side interaction, the length of the rod increases (especially in R -4), and the width of the rod decreases, leading to the increased aspect ratio in R -2, R -3, and R -4 (d–f). The summarized simulation and experiment results for the aspect ratio of crystals are shown in . Although the value of the aspect ratio in the simulation is about two times as that in the experiments, the main trend of the simulation results agrees well with the experimental findings. The difference of the absolute values between the simulation and experiment is mainly originated from the time scale used in the BD simulation (∼ms), which is much shorter than that in the experiments (∼h). Such a difference may be weakened when the simulated rods begin to aggregate with each other at a longer time.

elements.content: Obviously, molecular simulations support a close relationship between the morphology (or aspect ratio) and the strength of the interchain interactions involving counterions in these positively charged chain compounds, which agree well with the experimental results. As far as we are aware, a similar study has never been described in the literature. Moreover, the presence of different counteranions also influences the local coordination environment of the DyIII ion in 1–4, which is reflected by their magnetic behavior.

elements.content: Since the enantiomers possess similar magnetic behaviors, only the magnetic properties of R -1, R -2, R -3, and R -4 are investigated in detail. The dc magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples in the temperature range 1.9–300 K under an applied magnetic field of 1 kOe. As shown in , the room temperature χM T values per Dy are 14.15, 14.10, 13.79, and 13.90 cm3·K·mol–1 for R -1, R -2, R -3, and R –4, respectively, which are consistent with the value of 14.17 cm3 ·K· mol–1 expected from the free-ion approximation of DyIII ion (S = 5/2, L = 5, 6 H 15/2, g = 4/3). Upon cooling, the χM T values slightly decrease over the temperature range 300–25 K and then drop abruptly to 8.22, 7.49, 7.79, and 9.34 cm3·K·mol–1 at 2.0 K for the four compounds, respectively, in line with the thermal depopulation of the M J states of the DyIII ion.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Since the enantiomers possess similar magnetic behaviors, only the magnetic properties of  R  -1,  R  -2,  R  -3, and  R  -4 are investigated in detail. The dc magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples in the temperature range 1.9-300 K under an applied magnetic field of 1 kOe. As shown in , the room temperature χM T values per Dy are 14.15, 14.10, 13.79, and 13.90 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 for  R  -1,  R  -2,  R  -3, and  R  -4, respectively, which are consistent with the value of 14.17 cm3 ⋅K⋅ mol-1 expected from the free-ion approximation of DyIII ion (S = 5/2, L = 5, 6 H 15/2, g = 4/3). Upon cooling, the χM T values slightly decrease over the temperature range 300-25 K and then drop abruptly to 8.22, 7.49, 7.79, and 9.34 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 2.0 K for the four compounds, respectively, in line with the thermal depopulation of the M J states of the DyIII ion.

elements.content: The field dependence of magnetization was determined at a field of 0–70 kOe between 2 and 10 K (Figure S30). The M versus H curves of 1–4 display a linear increase at low field and then slowly reach the values of 5.4, 5.10, 4.88, and 5.29 Nβ at 7 T at 1.9 or 2.0 K, less than the saturated value of 10 Nβ for one DyIII ion. The corresponding M vs H/T curves deviate from one another (, inset), indicating the presence of magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states.

elements.content: Compared to static magnetic properties, the dynamic properties of lanthanide SMMs appear to be more sensitive to a subtle change of crystal field. The dynamics of the magnetization for R -1, R -2, R -3, and R -4 were investigated via alternating current (ac) susceptibility measurements on PPMS at frequencies of 10–10000 Hz under an oscillating 5 Oe ac field. Under zero dc field, all compounds show frequency-dependent in-phase (χ′) and out-of-phase (χ″) signals, indicating slow magnetization relaxation, which is characteristic of SMM behavior.
elements.clean_text: Compared to static magnetic properties, the dynamic properties of lanthanide SMMs appear to be more sensitive to a subtle change of crystal field. The dynamics of the magnetization for  R  -1,  R  -2,  R  -3, and  R  -4 were investigated via alternating current (ac) susceptibility measurements on PPMS at frequencies of 10-10000 Hz under an oscillating 5 Oe ac field. Under zero dc field, all compounds show frequency-dependent in-phase (χ') and out-of-phase (χ") signals, indicating slow magnetization relaxation, which is characteristic of SMM behavior.

elements.content: For R -1 and R -4, distinct peaks of the χ″ signals are invisible above 1.8 K, making it impossible to estimate the energy barrier of spin reversal by fitting the Arrhenius expression. It is well-known that the application of external dc field could suppress quantum tunneling of magnetization (QTM) and hence slow the magnetization reversal. In the present cases, however, the presence of external dc field up to 2 kOe accelerates the relaxation (Figures S31–S34), unlike many other dysprosium systems.

elements.content: For compound R -2, the frequency scan of the χ″ signals exhibits two distinct peaks at low temperatures, suggesting a dual relaxation process (a). When the temperature increases, both the low- (slow relaxation, SR) and high-frequency (fast relaxation, FR) peak intensities decline. The CC-FIT program was used to fit the ac susceptibility data. Since the fast relaxation process almost disappears above 9 K, the relaxation times were extracted by fitting the Cole–Cole plots using the generalized Debye model for the data in the temperature 9–15 K, and a linear combination of two modified Debye models for the data in the temperature range 1.8–8 K (b). As shown in c, both the SR and FR processes show a linear temperature dependence of ln τ at high temperature region corresponding to an Orbach relaxation mechanism, but deviate significantly from the linearity at lower temperatures. The Arrhenius fit of the data in the high temperature region resulted in the energy barrier (U eff) and the pre-exponential factor (τ0) of 79.6 K and 2.86 × 10–8 s for the SR process, and 26.6 K and 2.74 × 10–7 s for the FR process. The data in the whole temperature range (1.8–15 K) were fit by in which the Orbach, Raman, and direct mechanisms are considered. t − 1 = t 0 − 1 exp ( − U eff / k T ) + C T n + A T

elements.content: For the SR process, the best fit resulted parameters U eff = 79.1 K, τ0 = 3.46 × 10–8 s, C = 169 s–1 K–1.67, n = 1.67, and A = 0. Obviously the Orbach and Raman mechanisms are dominant in the SR process. For the FR process, the best fit led to parameters U eff = 37.6 K, τ0 = 8.50 × 10–7 s, and A = 3738 K–1 s–1. The n value is extremely small (n = 1.2 × 10–27), suggesting that the Orbach and direct mechanisms are dominant in the FR process with negligible contribution from Raman process.

elements.content: With regard to compound R -3, a dual relaxation process was also observed below 15 K (d–e). The ln τ vs T –1 profiles for R -3 are similar to those for R -2 (f). Suppose that only Orbach and Raman mechanisms are operative in the SR process, like in the case of compound R -2, the parameters become U eff = 80.0 K, τ0 = 2.62 × 10–8 s, C = 216 s–1 K–1.94, n = 1.94. The FR process in R -3 is again governed by the Orbach and direct mechanisms with U eff = 39.1 K, τ0 = 3.24 × 10–8 s, A = 5038 K–1 s–1. The energy barriers for compounds R -2 and R -3 are comparable to a few other Dy-SMMs with chain structures (Table S16).

elements.content: The observation of different magnetic behaviors in the four compounds must originate from their structural differences. For a dysprosium chain compound, the overall magnetic anisotropy is a collective result of single-ion magnetic anisotropy of the DyIII ions and intrachain interactions. The exchange couplings mediated through the μ-O­(P) and O–P–O bridges are extremely weak, evidenced by the magnetic studies on a Gd analogue of compound R -2, which shows a Weiss constant of +1.37 K (Figure S40). Hence from the magnetic point of view, compounds 1–4 may be viewed as chains of SMMs/SIMs. As the single-ion anisotropy is highly sensitive to the ligand field and the coordination geometry (or symmetry) of the DyIII ion, it is important to compare the coordination geometries of the DyIII ions in these compounds. As shown in Table S15, compound R -1 contains six crystallographically distinguished DyIII ions, half of which (Dy1, Dy2, Dy3) show distorted square antiprism with D 4d symmetry. But the other half (Dy4, Dy5, Dy6) show distorted triangular dodecahedron (D 2d) or capped trigonal prism (C 2v) with lower symmetry. In compound R -4, all the 11 crystallographically different DyIII ions show geometries with D 2d or C 2v symmetry. On the contrary, compounds R -2 and R -3 each contain three crystallographically distinct DyIII ions, two of which (Dy2, Dy3) have square antiprism geometries with D 4d symmetry, and one (Dy1) shows capped trigonal prism geometry with C 2v symmetry. The difference in the coordination geometries of the DyIII ions in these chain compounds may explain why the SMM behavior is evident for compounds R -2 and R -3 with peaks appearing in the χ″ vs frequency curves above 1.8 K but not for compounds R -1 and R -4.

But the other half (Dy4, Dy5, Dy6) show distorted triangular dodecahedron (D 2d) or capped trigonal prism (C 2v) with lower symmetry. In compound  R  -4, all the 11 crystallographically different DyIII ions show geometries with D 2d  or C 2v  symmetry. On the contrary, compounds  R  -2 and  R  -3 each contain three crystallographically distinct DyIII ions, two of which (Dy2, Dy3) have square antiprism geometries with D 4d  symmetry, and one (Dy1) shows capped trigonal prism geometry with C 2v  symmetry. The difference in the coordination geometries of the DyIII ions in these chain compounds may explain why the SMM behavior is evident for compounds  R  -2 and  R  -3 with peaks appearing in the χ" vs frequency curves above 1.8 K but not for compounds  R  -1 and  R  -4.

elements.content: The observation of two thermally activated relaxation processes with remarkably different relaxation times in compounds R -2 and R -3 is also interesting. In Dy-based SMMs, such phenomenon is often associated with the presence of nonequivalent DyIII ions and/or the intra- and intermolecular interactions. In the present cases, the dual relaxation could stem from the presence of three distinct Dy atoms with two types of coordination geometries in the two compounds, e.g., square antiprism geometries with D 4d symmetry and capped trigonal prism geometry with C 2v symmetry. As far as we are aware, a dual relaxation process in a dysprosium chain compound has never been described thus far.

In the present cases, the dual relaxation could stem from the presence of three distinct Dy atoms with two types of coordination geometries in the two compounds, e.g., square antiprism geometries with D 4d  symmetry and capped trigonal prism geometry with C 2v  symmetry. As far as we are aware, a dual relaxation process in a dysprosium chain compound has never been described thus far.

elements.content: Four pairs of enantiomeric DyIII phosphonates have been successfully isolated, where the positively charged Dy/pemp chains are separated by counteranions such as NO3 –, Cl–, Br–, and CF3SO3 –. The morphology study on the R-isomers shows that the aspect ratio changes with different anions and follows the sequence: R -1 (NO3 –) < R -2 (Cl–) < R -3 (Br–) < R -4 (CF3SO3 –). The sequence agrees well with the decreasing interchain interactions involving counteranions, supported by molecular simulations. Moreover, the counteranions also show prominent influences on the intrachain structures and the local coordination geometries of the DyIII ions. Consequently, a distinct single molecule magnet behavior with dual relaxation process is observed for compounds R -2 and R -3. For compounds R -1 and R -4, slow magnetic relaxation is also observed at zero dc field but without the appearance of maxima down to 1.8 K. This work provides a new strategy with general applicability in modulating not only the morphology but also the function of charged chain compounds by counterions, which is useful in tailoring and optimizing the functions of chain-based molecular materials, especially those combining chirality and magnetism, for further applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Four pairs of enantiomeric DyIII phosphonates have been successfully isolated, where the positively charged Dy/pemp chains are separated by counteranions such as NO3 -, Cl-, Br-, and CF3SO3 -. The morphology study on the R-isomers shows that the aspect ratio changes with different anions and follows the sequence:  R  -1 (NO3 -) <  R  -2 (Cl-) <  R  -3 (Br-) <  R  -4 (CF3SO3 -). The sequence agrees well with the decreasing interchain interactions involving counteranions, supported by molecular simulations. Moreover, the counteranions also show prominent influences on the intrachain structures and the local coordination geometries of the DyIII ions. Consequently, a distinct single molecule magnet behavior with dual relaxation process is observed for compounds  R  -2 and  R  -3. For compounds  R  -1 and  R  -4, slow magnetic relaxation is also observed at zero dc field but without the appearance of maxima down to 1.8 K. This work provides a new strategy with general applicability in modulating not only the morphology but also the function of charged chain compounds by counterions, which is useful in tailoring and optimizing the functions of chain-based molecular materials, especially those combining chirality and magnetism, for further applications.

cln_elements.content:
Thermal analyses show a two-step decomposition for 1 (Figure S13). The weight losses below 100 °C are 4.1% for R -1 and 3.9% for S -1, attributed to the release of 12 water molecules (calcd: 4.1%). The dehydrated samples are stable up to 220 °C, above which a second-step weight-loss is observed with collapse of the structures. For compounds 2 and 3, the weight losses below 200 °C are 1.5% for R -2, 1.2% for S -2, and 0.3% for R -3 and S -3, attributed to the removal of two and a half water molecules (calcd: 1.4% for 2, 0.3% for 3), respectively. After increasing of the temperature to 260 °C, a second-step weight-loss is observed with collapse of the structures (Figures S14 and S15). For compound 4, thermal analysis reveals a weight loss of 3.9% for R -4 and 3.6% for S -4 on heating to 100 °C, corresponding to the release of 22 lattice water molecules (calcd: 3.9%). A plateau appears between 100 and 260 °C, suggesting that the dehydrated compound is stable up to 260 °C. Above 260 °C, the compound is decomposed, and the structure is collapsed (Figure S16).

Magnetic Properties

Since the enantiomers possess similar magnetic behaviors, only the magnetic properties of R -1, R -2, R -3, and R -4 are investigated in detail. The dc magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples in the temperature range 1.9–300 K under an applied magnetic field of 1 kOe. As shown in , the room temperature χM T values per Dy are 14.15, 14.10, 13.79, and 13.90 cm3·K·mol–1 for R -1, R -2, R -3, and R –4, respectively, which are consistent with the value of 14.17 cm3 ·K· mol–1 expected from the free-ion approximation of DyIII ion (S = 5/2, L = 5, 6 H 15/2, g = 4/3). Upon cooling, the χM T values slightly decrease over the temperature range 300–25 K and then drop abruptly to 8.22, 7.49, 7.79, and 9.34 cm3·K·mol–1 at 2.0 K for the four compounds, respectively, in line with the thermal depopulation of the M J states of the DyIII ion.

Magnetic Properties

Since the enantiomers possess similar magnetic behaviors, only the magnetic properties of  R  -1,  R  -2,  R  -3, and  R  -4 are investigated in detail. The dc magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples in the temperature range 1.9-300 K under an applied magnetic field of 1 kOe. As shown in , the room temperature χM T values per Dy are 14.15, 14.10, 13.79, and 13.90 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 for  R  -1,  R  -2,  R  -3, and  R  -4, respectively, which are consistent with the value of 14.17 cm3 ⋅K⋅ mol-1 expected from the free-ion approximation of DyIII ion (S = 5/2, L = 5, 6 H 15/2, g = 4/3). Upon cooling, the χM T values slightly decrease over the temperature range 300-25 K and then drop abruptly to 8.22, 7.49, 7.79, and 9.34 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 2.0 K for the four compounds, respectively, in line with the thermal depopulation of the M J states of the DyIII ion.
